name: Einstein problem
rephrased: Prove that there exists a single shape (an 'einstein') that can tile the plane without forming a periodic pattern.
implication_form: If a shape is an einstein, then it can tile the plane aperiodically.
explained: The Einstein problem refers to the mathematical conjecture (or open problem) of finding a single aperiodic tile, known as an 'einstein', which can tile the plane (i.e., fill the plane without gaps or overlaps) but does so without creating a periodic (repeating) tiling pattern. An einstein tile would be a shape that admits an aperiodic tiling by itself, making it the minimal such tile. This problem remains unsolved; no such single tile has been found yet.
terms: The Einstein riddle (as a separate logic puzzle, despite the name misattribution)
related_conjectures: The original problem of finding a single aperiodic tile (Wang tiles)
The problem of finding a smaller set of tiles that form an aperiodic tiling (e.g., Penrose tiles)
